reference: Volume Seven, Issue Forty-Eight, File 1 of 18
title: Phrack 48
historical_context: This issue marks a significant transition for Phrack, with new editors taking over to ensure more regular publication amidst the challenges faced by the previous editorial team.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and enthusiasts of hacker culture.
short_summary: Phrack 48 introduces new editorial staff and discusses the challenges of maintaining a regular publication schedule. It features a variety of articles on hacking techniques, telecommunications, and security insights.
summary:
Phrack 48 is a notable issue that reflects the evolving landscape of hacker culture in the mid-1990s. The editorial staff acknowledges the difficulties in producing the magazine regularly, attributing delays to the pressures of daily life. With the introduction of new editors—Voyager, RedDragon, and Daemon9—there is a renewed hope for more timely releases. This issue serves as a rallying point for the community, emphasizing the importance of collaboration and shared knowledge among hackers and enthusiasts. The editors express gratitude to the community for their patience and support during this transition period.

The issue contains a diverse array of articles that delve into various aspects of hacking and telecommunications. Topics include Motorola command mode information, cellular phone hacking, and insights into electronic telephone cards. Additionally, there are discussions on IP spoofing and network monitoring, showcasing the technical depth and expertise of the contributors. Overall, Phrack 48 not only marks a new chapter for the magazine but also serves as a valuable resource for those interested in the technical intricacies of hacking and security during a pivotal time in the digital age.
